channel.title: NYT > World News
channel.copyright: Copyright 2022 The New York Times Company

item.title: Canada Live Updates: Ottawa Declares a State of Emergency Amid Trucker Protests
item.description: The protesters and their trucks remained entrenched in Ottawa’s downtown Monday morning after the Ottawa mayor had declared the emergency.
item.dc:creator: The New York Times

item.title: Ukraine Live Updates: Macron Meets With Putin; Says Europe Is at a ‘Critical Crossroads’
item.description: The French president said he hoped to begin a de-escalation in Russia’s military buildup surrounding Ukraine. President Biden was scheduled to meet with Olaf Scholz, the German chancellor, in the hope of strengthening Western nations’ response to Moscow.
item.dc:creator: The New York Times
item.media:credit: Cheriss May for The New York Times

item.title: Taiwan and China Are Both Closely Watching Ukraine Crisis
item.description: Taiwan knows what it’s like to have an overbearing neighbor. China wonders how forcefully Western powers might react to a Russian invasion.
item.dc:creator: Steven Lee Myers and Amy Qin
item.media:description: A view of the South China Sea last year, with the Chinese city of Xiamen in the distance and the Taiwanese islands of Kinmen in the foreground.

item.title: Turkey’s Doctors Are Leaving, the Latest Casualty of Spiraling Inflation
item.description: Doctors, worn down by grueling hours and violence, are emigrating in rising numbers, undermining one of President Recep Tayyip Erdogan’s signature achievements.
item.dc:creator: Carlotta Gall
item.media:credit: Ivor Prickett for The New York Times
item.media:description: A view of Istanbul. The worsening economy and soaring inflation in Turkey have reduced some doctors’ salaries close to the level of the minimum wage.

item.title: Syria’s Kurds Wanted Autonomy. They Got an Endless War.
item.description: The Kurds of northeastern Syria dreamed of establishing an autonomous, multiethnic and gender-equal utopia. Instead, their breakaway region has been engulfed in conflict since its creation.
item.dc:creator: Jane Arraf
item.category: Islamic State in Iraq and Syria (ISIS)
United States Defense and Military Forces
item.media:credit: Diego Ibarra Sanchez for The New York Times
item.media:description: Thousands attended the burial of 12 fighters from the Kurdish-led forces who were killed while battling Islamic State militants who took over a prison.

item.title: Sudan's 'Resistance Committees' Take On the Generals
item.description: Hundreds of loosely connected “resistance committees” are organizing nonviolent protests, tracking the injured and dead and demanding a government led by civilians.
item.dc:creator: Abdi Latif Dahir and Faiz Abubakar Muhamed
item.media:credit: Faiz Abubakar Muhamed for The New York Times
item.media:description: A protest in front of the family home of a 22 year old protester Thabit Moawya Bashir killed on Jan 24, in Khartoum, Sudan, on Jan 27, 2022 .

item.title: Ottawa Mayor Declares State of Emergency Amid Antigovernment Protests
item.description: A 10-day demonstration by truckers and other protesters has ensnarled Canada’s capital and led officials to warn that things could turn violent.
item.dc:creator: Ian Austen and Dan Bilefsky
item.media:description: Protesters in Ottawa on Sunday.

item.title: Afghanistan’s Health Care System Is Collapsing Under Stress
item.description: Hospitals and clinics are struggling to hold up amid a cash shortage and a vast surge of malnutrition and disease. By one estimate, 90 percent may close in the next few months.
item.dc:creator: David Zucchino, Safiullah Padshah and Jim Huylebroek
item.media:description: A nurse tends to a child at an Intensive Care Unit for severe cases at the Indira Gandhi Children’s Hospital in Kabul, Afghanistan, this month.

item.title: Biden Will Press German Chancellor on Russia Sanctions and Pipeline
item.description: The two leaders are meeting amid concerns that Germany has not been a forceful enough partner in calming tensions between Russia and Ukraine.
item.dc:creator: Katie Rogers
item.media:credit: Cheriss May for The New York Times
item.media:description: President Biden will hold his first meeting with Chancellor Olaf Scholz of Germany.

item.title: Africa Cup of Nations: Soccer Tournament Offers Joy Amid Coups and Covid
item.description: Many countries competing in the Africa Cup of Nations are enduring security, economic and political crises, but the tournament has brought delight and solidarity.
item.dc:creator: Ruth Maclean, Brenda Kiven and Tom Saater
item.category: Coups D'Etat and Attempted Coups D'Etat
item.media:credit: Tom Saater for The New York Times
item.media:description: Senegalese fans in Yaoundé, Cameroon, on Wednesday. The Africa Cup of Nations tournament has brought some respite for countries going through major political upheavals, war and the pandemic.

item.title: Queen Elizabeth Commemorates Platinum Jubilee, Marking 70-Year Reign
item.description: The milestone puts the queen, 95, in rarefied company: Only three other monarchs are documented to have reigned for more than 70 years.
item.dc:creator: Mark Landler
item.category: Elizabeth II, Queen of Great Britain
George VI, King of Great Britain
item.media:description: Queen Elizabeth II at Sandringham, her country estate, on Saturday. She plans to spend a quiet Sunday there, with jubilee celebrations scheduled for June.

item.title: Lata Mangeshkar, Bollywood’s Most Beloved Voice, Dies at 92
item.description: Ms. Mangeshkar, a revered figure in India, recorded songs for countless films — not appearing onscreen herself, but providing characters’ singing voices.
item.dc:creator: Shalini Venugopal Bhagat
item.media:description: Lata Mangeshkar in 2009. “If we play her songs one by one, we could hear her for a month and never hear the same song again,” said one of the many actresses who worked with her.

item.title: U.S. Warns of Grim Toll if Putin Pursues Full Invasion of Ukraine
item.description: Biden administration officials told lawmakers that a large-scale Russian invasion could kill as many as 50,000 civilians and prompt a refugee crisis in Europe.
item.dc:creator: Helene Cooper and David E. Sanger
item.category: Coups D'Etat and Attempted Coups D'Etat
item.media:description: An arrangement of ballistic missiles in Belarus late last month. President Vladimir V. Putin of Russia could strike Ukrainian targets before sending any troops over the border.

item.title: Effort to Rescue a 5-Year-Old Transfixes Morocco, Only to End Sadly
item.description: The four-day rescue operation failed to save the life of Rayan, who plunged down a 100-foot well, a devastating outcome to the many Moroccans who were captivated by the effort to save him.
item.dc:creator: Vivian Yee, Aida Alami and Mona El-Naggar
item.media:description: Rescue workers carried Rayan Oram, 5, to an ambulance in Ighrane, Morocco, on Saturday. The boy, who fell down a 100-foot well on Tuesday, was declared dead soon after he was dug out.

item.title: BA.2 Omicron Subvariant Gains In Europe, But May Not Change Much
item.description: Though the BA.2 subvariant spreads more readily, it does not appear to cause more serious disease than the BA.1 version of Omicron, the coronavirus variant that drove the latest global surge.
item.dc:creator: Ron DePasquale
item.media:credit: Liselotte Sabroe/Ritzau Scanpix Foto, via Associated Press
item.media:description: Denmark is ending pandemic restrictions even though an even more contagious version of the Omicron variant has become dominant there. Passengers waited for a bus in Copenhagen last week.

item.title: Marc Overmars, Dutch Soccer Star, Quits Post After Admitting to Inappropriate Texts
item.description: Marc Overmars, a former player who became a director at Ajax, one of Europe’s top clubs, apologized for his actions. The club said he had “gone over the line.”
item.dc:creator: Claire Moses
item.media:description: Marc Overmars at Ajax’s stadium in Amsterdam last May.

item.title: Who are the protesters and what do they want?
item.description: The demonstrators are a diverse collection of people animated by fatigue over pandemic restrictions, seeking something that is not in the federal government’s power to grant.
item.dc:creator: Dan Bilefsky
item.media:description: Vehicles clogged downtown streets near Parliament Hill in Ottawa on Saturday as truckers and supporters continued a protest against Covid-19 vaccine mandates, and pandemic restrictions more generally.

item.title: Why Americans Are Slow to Get Booster Shots
item.description: Why are Americans slow to get booster shots?
item.dc:creator: David Leonhardt
item.media:credit: Kenny Holston for The New York Times
item.media:description: Getting a booster shot in Washington, D.C.

item.title: Li Wenliang, Doctor Who Warned of Covid, Is Still Mourned in China
item.description: Social media users flocked to an online profile for Dr. Li Wenliang, who provided an early warning about the coronavirus in 2019.
item.dc:creator: Joy Dong
item.media:description: Posters in memory of Li Wenliang and other doctors near a hospital in Wuhan, China, on the anniversary of Dr. Li’s death last year.

item.title: A Photographer’s View of Jordan’s Many Splendors
item.description: For 10 days, a photojournalist drove across Jordan from north to south, visiting several of the country’s most treasured sites. Here’s what he saw.
item.dc:creator: Daniel Rodrigues

item.title: Is the Coronavirus in Your Backyard?
item.description: White-tailed deer could become a reservoir for the virus, putting people and animals at risk, health experts say.
item.dc:creator: Emily Anthes and Sabrina Imbler
item.media:credit: Hannah Yoon for The New York Times
item.media:description: Suresh Kuchipudi, a veterinary microbiologist at Penn State University in State College, Pa., with Cashew, a young white-tailed deer in the university’s deer research center.

item.title: Your Monday Briefing
item.description: Macron tries to mediate the Ukraine crisis.
item.dc:creator: Natasha Frost
item.media:description: As President Emmanuel Macron of France assumes the role of global peacemaker, he must balance the “new European security order” he seeks with his commitments to the United States and NATO.

item.title: Your Monday Briefing: The Olympics Begin
item.description: Plus Russia’s growing troop presence and Afghanistan’s collapsing health system.
item.dc:creator: Amelia Nierenberg
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces
Elizabeth II, Queen of Great Britain
item.media:description: Dancers performing at the ceremony on Friday in the Bird’s Nest stadium, which was also used for the 2008 Summer Olympics.

item.title: Teenage Inmates in Syria Lack Food and Medicine, Aid Group Says
item.description: UNICEF was given the first glimpse of teenage detainees at a prison attacked by ISIS two weeks ago in northeastern Syria.
item.dc:creator: Jane Arraf
item.category: Islamic State in Iraq and Syria (ISIS)
item.media:credit: Diego Ibarra Sanchez for The New York Times
item.media:description: The aftermath of clashes between U.S.-backed Kurdish forces and ISIS fighters last month in Hasaka, Syria.

item.title: Haiti Opposition Group Calls on U.S. to End Support for Current Government
item.description: With tensions rising, many see Monday as a deadline for the government to step down.
item.dc:creator: Maria Abi-Habib and Natalie Kitroeff
item.media:description: Prime Minister Ariel Henry in Cap-Haitien, Haiti, in December.

item.title: Macron Tries to Avert a European War and Reshape European Security
item.description: The French president’s shuttle diplomacy this week in Moscow and Kyiv will be a delicate exercise, given European reservations and American resolve.
item.dc:creator: Roger Cohen and Andrew E. Kramer
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces
item.media:description: As President Emmanuel Macron of France assumes the role of global peacemaker, he must balance the “new European security order” he seeks with his commitments to the United States and NATO.

item.title: India Beats England in Under-19 Cricket World Cup
item.description: The team’s ability to clinch a record fifth under-19 title despite a Covid outbreak underscored the vast pool of talent in India as it consolidates its place as a powerhouse in the sport.
item.dc:creator: Mujib Mashal
item.media:description: India’s youth cricket team celebrating after its victory over England over the weekend.

item.title: A Climate Opportunity
item.description: Biden’s big climate goals depend on Congress.
item.dc:creator: German Lopez
item.media:credit: Karsten Moran for The New York Times
item.media:description: President Biden's Build Back Better bill would include tax credits for residential solar power installations, like this one in Brooklyn.

item.title: Germany’s ‘Invisible’ Chancellor Heads to Washington Amid Fierce Criticism
item.description: Olaf Scholz will try to repair Germany’s credibility in the Ukraine crisis when he meets President Biden on Monday. Next on his agenda: Kyiv and Moscow.
item.dc:creator: Katrin Bennhold
item.media:description: Chancellor Olaf Scholz, center, on Wednesday in Berlin. He has been mocked as “nearly invisible, inaudible.”

item.title: Queen Elizabeth Paves the Way for Camilla to One Day Be Called Queen
item.description: On the eve of the 70th anniversary of the start of her reign, Elizabeth said she wanted the Duchess of Cornwall to hold the title of Queen Consort once Prince Charles is king.
item.dc:creator: Vimal Patel
item.category: Elizabeth II, Queen of Great Britain
item.media:description: Queen Elizabeth II with Camilla, the Duchess of Cornwall, in 2013.

item.title: Truck Protest Against Pandemic Measures Spreads Across Canada
item.description: A demonstration that began last weekend in Ottawa against vaccine mandates expanded on Saturday, and others took place in Toronto and Quebec City.
item.dc:creator: Ian Austen and Vjosa Isai
item.media:description: Protests against pandemic restrictions in Ottawa on Saturday.

item.title: Afghan Refugees Face Two-Tier System in Europe
item.description: Educated elites evacuated to Europe after the Taliban’s return are welcomed, but they struggle with their lives in exile, even as their poorer compatriots are shunned.
item.dc:creator: Matina Stevis-Gridneff
item.category: Middle East and Africa Migrant Crisis
item.media:credit: Eirini Vourloumis for The New York Times
item.media:description: A group of legislators, lawyers and judges who fled Afghanistan gathered in December at Melissa Network, a nongovernmental organization in Athens that supports women migrants and refugees.

item.title: The Morning: Why we travel
item.description: We travel not just to escape, but to find novelty, new heights and new sensations.
item.dc:creator: Melissa Kirsch

item.title: Ottawa Residents Fed Up With Trucker Convoy Protests
item.description: Although the focus has been on protests in front of Parliament, three Ottawa neighborhoods have also been upturned by the demonstrations.
item.dc:creator: Ian Austen
item.media:credit: Nasuna Stuart-Ulin for The New York Times
item.media:description: Protesters on Parliament Hill a week ago.

item.title: Fahad Shah, Editor in Kashmir, Is Arrested
item.description: The police accused Fahad Shah, who edits a news website, of “uploading anti-national content.” Critics say journalists in Kashmir have increasingly been harassed and intimidated.
item.dc:creator: Mujib Mashal
item.category: Human Rights and Human Rights Violations
item.media:description: Fahad Shah, right, editor of The Kashmir Walla, last month. His arrest showed the Kashmir authorities’ “utter disregard for press freedom,” the Committee to Protect Journalists said.

item.title: Collateral Damage of China's Virus Policy: Fruit
item.description: The closure of Chinese land borders and the tightened screening of goods have driven Southeast Asian fruit farmers into debt. Many have had to abandon their harvest.
item.dc:creator: Vo Kieu Bao Uyen, Sui-Lee Wee and Muktita Suhartono
item.media:credit: Linh Pham for The New York Times
item.media:description: Pham Thanh Hong, a dragon fruit farmer in Vietnam, trimming his trees, which were adorned with LED lights to induce off-season flowering.

item.title: Leader’s Death Is Another Blow for ISIS, but It’s Hardly the End
item.description: The Islamic State is a shadow of its former self. But it’s likely to keep adapting and enduring, even after the U.S. raid that killed its top commander.
item.dc:creator: Ben Hubbard
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces
Islamic State in Iraq and Syria (ISIS)
item.media:credit: Diego Ibarra Sanchez for The New York Times
item.media:description: American and Kurdish forces confronted ISIS fighters recently in Syria, in some of the heaviest fighting by U.S. troops in the region in three years.

item.title: Facing Tough Election, Orban Turns to Putin for Support
item.description: The Hungarian leader made his name by defying Moscow. But he has increasingly turned toward Russia in an effort to secure the natural gas he needs to keep energy prices low and voters happy.
item.dc:creator: Benjamin Novak and Andrew Higgins
item.media:description: Prime Minister Viktor Orban of Hungary, long seen as a political chameleon, has broken with his country’s long history of wariness toward Russia.

item.title: All Options Are Not on the Table as Biden Moves Troops Closer to Ukraine
item.description: The president’s opposition to sending U.S. troops into Ukraine reflects the mood of a war-wary Washington, as well as concerns about Russia’s nuclear arsenal.
item.dc:creator: Michael Crowley
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces
item.media:credit: Kenny Holston for The New York Times
item.media:description: The United States is deploying troops to NATO countries in Eastern Europe, but not to Ukraine, which is not a member of NATO.

item.title: ‘Guernica’ Antiwar Tapestry Is Rehung at U.N.
item.description: The canvas replica of Picasso’s painting, symbolizing war’s horrors, had been a photogenic fixture at the United Nations for decades before its owner, the Rockefeller family, removed it last year.
item.dc:creator: Rick Gladstone
item.media:description: The floor-to-ceiling reproduction of Pablo Picasso’s “Guernica” was a fixture outside the United Nations Security Council before it was removed in February of last year.

item.title: A judge lets seven Virginia school districts keep their mask policies in place.
item.dc:creator: Alexandra E. Petri
item.media:description: Students leaving Washington-Liberty High School in Arlington County, Va. It is in one of several school districts that has sued to stop the mask-optional order by Gov. Glenn Youngkin.

item.title: Southwest Airlines to Start Selling Alcohol on Flights Again
item.description: A flight attendants’ union said the decision was “unsafe and irresponsible.”
item.dc:creator: Vimal Patel
item.media:credit: Stefani Reynolds for The New York Times
item.media:description: Southwest Airlines plans to resume serving alcohol on flights in two weeks. The union representing flight attendants is worried that passengers who drink may become unruly in the skies.

item.title: Younger Americans Benefited Less From Booster Shots Than Older People
item.description: Among those under age 50, vaccination even without a booster protected strongly against hospitalization and death, according to new C.D.C. data.
item.dc:creator: Apoorva Mandavilli
item.category: Centers for Disease Control and Prevention
item.media:description: Administering a booster in the Bronx last month. The data suggest that boosters are most essential for older adults and those who have certain immune conditions or live in long-term care facilities.

item.title: Rescuers in Morocco Race to Save 5-Year-Old Stuck in Well for Days
item.description: People in the region were glued to the rescue effort on television and online, eager for some good news at a time when many have been buffeted by Covid pandemic gloom.
item.dc:creator: Vivian Yee, Dan Bilefsky and Aida Alami
item.media:description: Rescuers working on Friday to save a 5-year-old child who fell down a well in northern Morocco.

item.title: They Survived Guns and Machetes in Congo. They Want the World to Know.
item.description: After a brazen assault on a displaced persons camp that killed about 60 people, the most seriously wounded were airlifted to a hospital where a Times photographer recorded their accounts.
item.dc:creator: Finbarr O’Reilly
item.category: War Crimes, Genocide and Crimes Against Humanity
item.media:description: Logo Lupka, 65, had fled his village only a week before the attack on the camp. He was shot in the hip, but his wife was shot and killed in the tent beside him. “Only God can help me now,” he said.

item.title: Russian Troops in Final Stages of Readiness Add to Worries for Ukraine
item.description: Though the Kremlin’s intentions are unclear, Ukrainian officials are newly worried about the Crimean Peninsula, where Russia has deployed 10,000 additional troops, they said.
item.dc:creator: Michael Schwirtz
item.media:description: A satellite image released this month by Maxar shows Russian battle groups and tents in Bakhchysarai, Crimea.

item.title: Lone ISIS Bomber Carried Out Kabul Airport Attack, U.S. Says
item.description: The suicide bombing killed as many as 170 civilians and 13 U.S. troops in the final days of U.S. military involvement in Afghanistan.
item.dc:creator: Eric Schmitt and Helene Cooper
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces
Islamic State in Iraq and Syria (ISIS)
item.media:credit: Victor J. Blue for The New York Times
item.media:description: Victims of a suicide bombing at the airport in Kabul, Afghanistan, arrived at a hospital in August.

item.title: The C.D.C. Adds Wastewater Data to Its Covid-19 Tracker
item.description: Analyzing wastewater can help officials estimate how prevalent the virus is in a community and which variants are circulating.
item.dc:creator: Emily Anthes
item.category: Centers for Disease Control and Prevention
item.media:description: A wastewater treatment plant and overflow facility in Farmington, W.Va., in October.

item.title: Ukraine Shows Off New U.S. Weaponry, in a Signal to Russia
item.description: As the United States and others step up military aid to Ukraine, the deliveries are more overt, and Ukraine is staging public weapons demonstrations for the media.
item.dc:creator: Maria Varenikova
item.media:credit: Brendan Hoffman for The New York Times
item.media:description: A Ukrainian soldier demonstrates an American-provided M141 “bunker-buster” missile in Ukraine on Thursday.

item.title: In Beijing, Olympic Spectacle and Global Power Games
item.description: The opening of the Winter Games gave Xi Jinping and Vladimir V. Putin a chance to cement their partnership against Western censure.
item.dc:creator: Chris Buckley and Steven Lee Myers
item.media:description: China’s leader, Xi Jinping, at the Winter Olympics opening ceremony on Friday in Beijing.

item.title: India's Latest Covid Surge May Be Declining, Officials Say
item.description: “We are seeing the pandemic situation has improved,” said Dr. V.K. Paul, the head of India’s Covid task force.
item.dc:creator: Karan Deep Singh
item.media:description: Testing for the coronavirus in Jammu, India, last month.

item.title: Five Takeaways From the U.S. Raid That Killed the Islamic State’s Leader
item.description: A daring raid by U.S. Special Operations forces that resulted in the death of the ISIS leader offered a vivid reminder that the chaos in Syria continues to reverberate.
item.dc:creator: Shashank Bengali and Marc Santora
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces
Islamic State in Iraq and Syria (ISIS)
item.media:description: The house in Atmeh, Syria, in which Abu Ibrahim al-Hashimi al-Qurayshi, the leader of the Islamic State, was living.

item.title: Apathy and Anger in France’s Election Everytown
item.description: Auxerre has backed the winner in every French presidential race for 40 years. This time, the town’s politics are drifting right, and many struggling residents see little to vote for.
item.dc:creator: Léontine Gallois
item.media:credit: Dmitry Kostyukov for The New York Times
item.media:description: Auxerre has consistently voted for the winning presidential candidate for the past 40 years.

item.title: Pandemic-era tests could help efforts to eliminate hepatitis C.
item.dc:creator: Ted Alcorn
item.media:credit: Jovelle Tamayo for The New York Times
item.media:description: For many patients, navigating a complex pathway to treatment for hepatitis C can be “a big barrier,“ said Dr. Lucinda Grande.

item.title: Captain James Cook’s Ship Caught in Center of a Maritime Rift
item.description: After researchers in Australia reported finding the wreck of the Endeavour off Rhode Island, their U.S. partners issued a startling rebuke.
item.dc:creator: Manan Luthra
item.media:description: A replica of James Cook’s HMB Endeavour in Sydney. Experts say they may have found the shipwreck in Newport Harbor, R.I.

item.title: Zero Covid in China
item.description: China’s zero-Covid policy has kept deaths very low. Can it continue?
item.dc:creator: David Leonhardt and Ian Prasad Philbrick
item.media:credit: Chang W. Lee/The New York Times
item.media:description: A train station in Beijing where express trains connect Olympic venues.

item.title: How Randa Abd Al-Aziz, a Black Iraqi, Got a Sudden Career in TV News
item.description: Randa Abd Al-Aziz was joking with friends in a Baghdad cafe when she got a surprise job offer: broadcasting the news in Iraq, whose Black citizens have little media presence and even less power.
item.dc:creator: Jane Arraf
item.media:credit: Aline Deschamps for The New York Times
item.media:description: Randa Abd Al-Aziz is the only Black Iraqi who has been employed on air at the state television’s news and information channels in the last 20 years — and possibly ever.

item.title: On Ukraine, Many Russians Have No Doubt: It’s the Fault of the U.S.
item.description: The idea that the U.S. and NATO are fomenting the crisis between Russia and Ukraine is hammered home daily by the Kremlin’s propaganda machine.
item.dc:creator: Ivan Nechepurenko and Valerie Hopkins
item.media:credit: Sergey Ponomarev for The New York Times
item.media:description: In Moscow this week, where many Russians blamed the United States for the Ukraine crisis while others preferred not to think about it.

item.title: Talking Points With … Who Else? The Points Guy
item.description: Brian Kelly has been helping travelers and other consumers navigate the increasingly complicated loyalty universe for over a decade. Here’s what he has to say about playing the points game.
item.dc:creator: Elaine Glusac

item.title: New Zealand Inquiry Finds Hundreds of Reports of Abuse by Priests
item.description: The complaints, going back seven decades, attest to the pervasiveness of sexual and other abuse within the Catholic Church and are part of a worldwide reckoning.
item.dc:creator: Isabella Kwai
item.category: Survivors Network of Those Abused by Priests
item.media:description: A Mass in Auckland, New Zealand, in 2014.
